div1.p: Carr gives a clinical account of the illness and death of yellow fever victim Robert Sherman.

div1.head: History of a Case of Yellow Fever Occurred in Parahyba from 16 to 24/3/25, by G. Jameson Carr, March 25, 1925

p.hi: HISTORY OF A CASE OF YELLOW FEVER OCCURRED IN PARAHYBA FROM 16 to 24/3/25.

div1.p:
On the morning of the 16th, there arrived an American, at the
Hotel Luzo-Brasileiro, Robert Sherman, aged 50, mining engineer.
He stated on that day that he suffered from headache.

On the 17th, he remained in bed and Dr. Adhemar Londres, who
was one of the medical attendants of Mr. O'Donnell (case reported previously)
and who made the diagnosis, saw him and on the 18th, had him removed to
the local hospital S. Izabel. On learning this, I with Dr. Bião and Dr.
Londres visited him at 8 a.m. on the 20th and found the following conditions:-
March 20th - 8 a.m. - Flushed face, conjunctiva injected and icteritic,
also neck and chest as far as angle of Louis; gums
bleeding, but may be due to extensive pyorrhea.
Tongue furred with red tip and edges. Breath
cadaveric. Pains in head general. Nausea only.
Temperature 38, 2 C, pulse 82, respirations 20.
Blood pressure appeared high, pulse irregular in
rhythm. Liver enlarged two fingers breadth below
ninth costal cartilage and tender. Slightly
wandering in mind and contradictory in statements.
Urine bile coloured loaded with albumin. Some
petechial spots on the left anterior surface of
fore-arm. Stated that he had been vaccinated in
Pernambuco but had had small-pox before.
March 20th - 8 p.m. - In statusquo general. Vomited mucus and bright
blood. Pulse less pressure and more feeble. Has
distinct delirious intervals. Pulse, temperature
and respirations were not taken by the doctor.
They were attempting to put him in a small sit bath,
he weighing 300 lbs. very weak and delirious.
I dissuaded them and myself gave him a sponge bath.
5th day.. or 4th
March 21st - 4 p.m. - Temperature 38, 8 C, pulse 88, respirations 22.
Icterus more marked. More petechial spots. Pains
in stomach and nauses. Bleeding from nose and gums
at times. More delirious. Urine not conserved.
March 22nd - 10 a.m. - Took “Chefe da Prophylaxia Rural” together with Dr.
Biao and Dr. Londres to see case. More icterus.
More petechial spots, urine scant heavily stained,
albumin thick. Casts granulated and epithelial.
Pains marked in muscles. Pulse weak and irregular,
in rhythm. Very nauseated and occasional attempt
at vomiting. There was an aortic systolic murmur
heard best over the junction of the right third
costal cartilage with the manubrium sterni and
extending upwards and outwards towards the clavicle
(No stethoscope available).
March 22nd - 8 p.m. - Temperature 37, 2 C, pulse 84, respirations 22.
Quite delirious. Gave him enema, tarry result.
Pulse very weak. Icterus more marked.
8.
25/3/1925.
March 23rd - 4 p.m. - Temperature 99, 4 F,, pulse 100. Comatose. With
twitchings of arms still protopathic sensibility
marked. Not urine passed in 30 hours.
March 23rd - 8 p.m. - Passed urine, dark, about 100 ounces (I did not
see specimen). Skin clamy. Pulse very low pressure
96. Temperature 100 F. No vomiting. Comatose.
Pupils sluggish. Muscular twitchings of arms
and semi-sterterous breathing.
This would appear to be a severe case in a bad subject.
March 24th - 4 a.m. - Died at 4 o'clock.

Because of the indefiniteness of the man's statements, because
at first he was very suspicious of being in hospital and being visited by
so many doctors, and as I find he was a well known gambler and made his
living by that means, his movements were somewhat indeterminate. So far,
he definitely arrived from Itabayanna on the 16th March complaining of
headache. He stated he was there from the 12th to the 16th having been
in Recife and Campina Grande. Later I find that he had been in Parahyba
from the 24th to the 27th of February and from there had gone to Ita-
bayanna, where he stated, he remained two days.
